segments.text: Flower children would try to sell paper-made flowers or any kind of flowers for exorbitant prices, talk other children into joining with them.
and bring in whatever thing they could from home that could be sold for money.
You know, to buy food, because they was hungry.
Sell them, took a bath.
As far as a crime problem, they didn't create much.
As a nuisance problem, they worked.
How do you distinguish that with the hippies?
The hippies were not organized in the way they were.
They were, hippies more or less, were on a individualistic, I'll do my own thing, kick.
They weren't in groups.
There might be one or two or three running together, but not 50 or 75 as a group that all lived in one room.
They stunk about the same.
They were probably both still about the same, but they were not the organized.
commune type, as the class order was.
Any crime aspect of the hippies, other than just shoplifting or stealing?
They're just, at that time, they were more or less just a drag on society in that they would do
whatever it was, to make their own thing.
If they wanted a fountain pen, they went by the nearest post office to write a letter and steal a fountain pen on the counter.
If they didn't want a fountain pen, they took it in and out because somebody else might want one.
They weren't stealing.
It was just a way of existing.
If they wanted a bath, they went to the nearest pillow station restaurant, locked the door, and took their bath.
or they went to your local department store.
We've got people now that are doing the same thing.
They call them the street people.
The names change.
Your actions don't.
How would you describe any anti-war movement in Fort Worth in response to the anomaly?
Was there any in Fort Worth?
I can't answer that very well.
I don't know.
There wasn't enough to make a big impression on me.
And that would have been during the time, I think.
You would have noticed.
It was in the late 60s.
There wasn't enough of it to make any impression on me.
I don't know.
Okay.
Point that question on.
When something would occur, any kind of incident, either between blacks or between blacks and police, would this always be local people?
Is it possible sometimes to be an outside instigator?
Now, by local, you mean in this same neighborhood or within the same town?
Same town.
Some of that was in the right context in their area, or they weren't from someplace else?
No, frequently we've had disturbances or incidents come up where they were provoked or enlarged upon or more notoriety caused
by people from other parts of town or other neighborhoods entirely that were not involved in that incident at all.
They'd get like a commotion.
Any examples that you can come up with off hand?
One that I can personally go on, two or three, but one that I can personally go on is one I was involved in out here on Amanda and stopped our section of town called Stop Six.
We had a domestic disturbance, I believe it was, come up.
And we had a couple of cars respond to the call, which happened to be in front of a nigger's beer joint on Sunday afternoon.
Everybody's out walking the streets anyhow.
And upshot of it was, we wound up, we're going to take the mail
that was involved in the dispute to jail.
I don't remember now whether he was drunk, drunk in a public place.
What the charge was, when
A man that I didn't know, a black man I didn't know, started all kind of yelling and hollering, you're not going to take my brother, my brother this, my brother that.
I knew the black people were arresting.
I didn't know the man that did all the hollering.
I asked one of the local people that lived in stop six that hung around those beer joints all the time who that man was.
Nobody knew him.
He wasn't from around there.
This is a sample of the outside agitation that could provoke an incident.
I think nearly all, I don't know about now, but at one time, all of your racial riots started with a damned old nigger woman screaming.
that wasn't involved in the original incident.
I don't understand that.
If you've got a policeman, say a policeman out here arresting 18 and 19 year old blacks,
And then here comes a 25 to 45-year-old black female raising all kinds of hell, screaming and obscenities and everything else.
The public in that area gets a riot.
Practically all of your racial riots have involved that damned old black female.
It started with her being a holler.
I know you hit on it earlier, and this is a little repetitious question.
What did the male officer think when women started moving out into the law enforcement, into the field?
Generally, the officers that were working at that time
Of course, they grew up in their police experience, all males.
And at a time when physical involvement was required, you wouldn't want to be a partner with a female.
You wouldn't want her on the same call with you.
because at that time the general idea was to respect womanhood, not involved in the unpleasant scenes and actions that a policeman necessarily got involved in.
Wouldn't want her to call the names of policemen once.
I guess as big of an issue as anything else that she would not be capable of taking care of herself physically.
and that you'd have to take care of her, plus yourself, plus trying to solve the incidents you were involved in, would create a hardship for the man.
Plus, some of the officers' wives didn't want their husbands riding with females.
That's the other piece.
You make it sound like there's a question as to a woman's ability to do police work.
A woman is physically capable of doing some of the police work.
Very few of the women are emotionally capable.
There's necessarily a difference between male and female emotions.
There are some exceptions, but the ones, for the most part, that have been hired here, their physical requirements were not comparable to physical requirements for men.
So that if the officer is involved in a fight, most of the time, he can depend on the woman to take care of her share of it.
Give me an example.
I don't know how dominant women were on the .
Any examples from the ?
Did something occur at one point that said she didn't handle herself in this fight?
Well, at this particular point, let's take this issue.
At one time, while I was a sergeant, I was assigned to the patrol captain's office, working in there handling phone calls and people that came in with problems.
A cab driver came in, said, I've got a drunk up there in my cab.
He's too drunk to pay his fare.
I brought him here to get him put in jail.
I'm assigned to the office.
I catch an officer that's walking along the hall, which happens to be a female.
Tell her to go get the drunk out of the cab.
Put him in jail.
The captain said,
I don't think I ought to let a female do that by herself.
She might get hurt for me to get up off my butt and go help her.
She's the officer that's getting paid to do the job that her supervisor told her to do.
This is the attitude that exists.
A woman is physically incapable in some instances.
It wasn't a typical dunk.
This one wasn't even fighting.
That's what she gets paid for.
She gets a full salary.
Not a partial salary.
She gets a full salary.
That's what she hired out to do.
This type of thing.
Do you think women are accepted by men on the force today any more than they were?
Yes, they're accepted more.
There's more of them.
and the males have been exposed to them from the beginning, some of our younger officers.
But I don't necessarily see if that makes it any better.
So many times,
The females are necessarily different from the males.
And their assignments and job performance evaluations, friendships, are frequently based on sexual attraction rather than police performance.

What do you think of the tendency, I'm not sure what Fort Worth PD's policy is, but the tendency of police departments to seek out and hire college graduates or people with some of the hours of college as officers?
When I started, the requirement was high school education, high school diploma, or I think they called it GED.
In the mid-60s, they
Fort Worth, along with every other department of the country, got on a higher education kick, which has resulted here.
And I believe now they require either 20 or 30 hours of college education before you can even apply.
What do you think?
Are there benefits to this, you think, or is it just a remnant of it?
I think it's just a carryover.
Personally, a policeman's job is a good memory and common sense.
Distress.
on higher education, they're not going to improve the policeman a whole lot.
How is it justified when a person, what was the desire of having a higher educated police officer?
Oh, the higher the education, the more they pay you.
The higher the education, the more chance for advancement.

Some of the city's jobs or, well, even in the police department, they developed the policy there of up until they tended to be a high school education, the captain had to have college, the deputy chief had to have a master's degree,
To be a chief, you had to be a super wheel.
This type of evolution pushing our education.
How would you describe the way the Fort Worth Police Department worked with the FBI?
Was it a frequent thing, or infrequent, or beneficial, or pain?
FBI on a very favorable basis.
I knew, got acquainted with, and knew practically all of the officers, the FBI's info was in several endowments.
And I've never had a problem with any of them.
Well, when they got
the time I was assigned to internal affairs.
Frequently, they got complaints involving the same complaints I was making the investigation on.
They'd hold off doing anything until I finished my investigation and it just takes the results of mine.
That's what they basically hold the investigation on.
they got their rules they've got to go by and ours were not necessarily the same as theirs but uh we had no problem okay um
regarding illegal drug use, possession, and sales have weakened a lot in the past.
The laws concerning illegal drug use, sales, possession, all aspects of drugs seem to weaken over the past probably decade or so.
I'm not sure of the time frame.
Why has this occurred?
After using it.
If you have a statewide speeding limit at 40 miles per hour, 10% of your people are going to exceed that speed limit, regardless of what it is.
If 15% exceed it, and their average is 45, you're not going to raise that speed limit to 45 miles per hour.
But 10% are still going to exceed it.
In other words, you're going to have a 10% above that, regardless of what the limit is.
When you set that limit where the majority of your people abide by it and are reasonably comfortable with it, that is your acceptable law.
The same with your guns.
A drug, say alcohol, and 10% of the people are going to abuse it.
If you try prohibition, it don't work.
You've got to adjust to a medium that the majority of the people can live with and accept and be willing to abide by.
The law is too restrictive.
It's going to be violated so many times that you can't enforce it.
If it's too lenient, there are going to be such flagrant abuses that the public will require something to be done.
This is what's made the adjustment, I believe.
And you're more lenient.
At the same time, some of your drug laws are tightened up considerably.
Now, you have the cities, counties, states, and federals taking a mass property away from you.
It is convicted of drug sales, and they think they can prove it.
that this property was bought with money made from drug sales.
That's reasonable.
That's a hell of a lot tighter than it used to be, because it used to, you couldn't do that.
You can even take a man's home away from him if he thinks it's, or feel like he can feel that it was bought, but it resulted in the sale of the property.
It's not necessarily all Orleanian laws.
There have been other tatter laws passed too.
What do you think the police, what's your opinion of these changes, both the tightening and the weakening?
Well, my opinion wouldn't make a whole lot of difference because we're not really involved in it.
But your police department,
whether it's Fort Worth or anywhere else, is like any competitive business.
They're in a process of continuous change.
They're not a static organization that will remain the same from now on.
They've got to change the technology, the attitude, the laws that have been passed.
to the personnel that they're able to employ.
They've got to be adaptable to a constant change.
Because that's what the organization is.
OK.
Spent a year in internal affairs.
What do you remember most about that time?
How would you describe your time at Toronto Fair?
Oh, that gets kind of involved.
Really your internal affairs organization is set up to
investigate complaints involving police officers.
The complaints can be from the public, or the police officers, or the administration of the police department.
If a deputy chief or chief wants a certain thing investigated, he can request it.
The way ours is set up, or was at that time, they initiate no investigations on their own.
They operate strictly off of complaints.
And they make no recommendations.

We had the policy at that time that if it was an officer involved and a copy of the whole investigation would be turned over to his immediate supervisor for the first recommendation of what should be done.
Then it went to the

second level supervisor on up to the deputy chief of that particular division and then the results of all of it went to the chief who makes the final decision because that's what his job is and his decision is what it counts now he can concur he can change raise or lower but it's his decision that's got to be the final one
with the internal affairs section made no recommendation at all.
Another factor there is that your minority groups, ACLU, and some people that are not informed as much as they should be,
frequently harder for civilian review boards for police departments.
That is a real sore point with most departments because concerning most police activities, they can't even be explained to, much less understood by, so many of the civilian population.
And if the Civilian Review Board was appointed by somebody who didn't care for the police department to begin with or who responded to politics more than actual circumstances,
There could be a very definite drawback or detriment to any department.
By the internal affairs group being able to, or with the understanding of, making the full, thorough, complete investigation
and making no recommendations, turning it over to somebody else for that, it counteracts the, gives a good argument that we don't need a civilian review board.
We've got a group of people here that will make a complete thorough investigation and give you the results of it.
Now, then it's up to you to decide what to do next.
But we don't need anyone else investigating.
We'll make the investigation.
And we'll make it third.
At the time I was in there, which was several years ago, I read figures that the average internal affairs investigation cost $5,000.
I wouldn't doubt it.
That or probably more.
And it's certainly gone up since then.
Because it is a girl.
As complete as I can make it.
What else?
OK.
There was a period there where a lot of people were crying out about police brutality this and police brutality that.
Do you think Peachtree County really ever was anything more than an isolated incident or two?
As a practice note, it was not an isolated incident.
Sure, you're going to have it.
You're going to have it in any business you're in.
If you've got a department with a thousand men.
To give you the classic example,
You're taught in school to treat everybody alike.
The first thing you learn when you get out working is that you can't treat everybody alike.
They don't expect you to and don't want you to.
Another is...
